titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory of the David Nelson Rowe papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Samira Bozorgi

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2016-01-21T15:40-0800
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Declassified U.S. government records returned to collection, assigned numbers of "missing" boxes; items from Box 1 that had been sent to preservation were reincorporated into the collection as Box 143 by Sarah Patton. Please see accession file for more details.
Declassified U.S. government records returned to collection.

physdesc.extent: 143 manuscript boxes, 1 oversize box, 1 oversize folder

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, notes, reports, printed matter, photographs, slides, phonotapes, microfilm, maps, postcards, and memorabilia relating to Chinese history and foreign relations, Asian area studies, Japanese World War II propaganda, application of the People's Republic of China for admission to the United Nations, and communism in Asia.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p:
Collection is open for research.
Collection is stored off site; a minimum of two days notice is required for use. Boxes may be requested through Stanford's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/
The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos or films during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all audiovisual material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], David Nelson Rowe papers, [Box number], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 1978, with increments received in 1981 and 1982.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the online catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

chronitem.event: Born in Nanking (Nanjing), China to American missionaries of the Methodist Episcopal Church

Completed postdoctoral study at Harvard University in Chinese and Japanese language and Chinese history

Lecturer in Far Eastern affairs, Princeton University

Died, Sun City, Arizona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection relates to Chinese history and foreign relations, Asian area studies, Japanese World War II propaganda, the application of the People's Republic of China for admission to the United Nations, and communism in Asia. It is comprised of correspondence, speeches and writings, notes, reports, printed matter, photographs, slides, sound recordings, microfilm, maps, posters, and postcards.

Of particular note in the collection are Japanese propaganda posters, flyers, and other visual materials depicting scenes from the Second Sino-Japanese War, likely collected by Rowe during his trips to the region and used as research materials for his writings on Japanese propaganda in North China and the development of psychological warfare strategies.

Pamphlets, monographs, and newsletters relating to communism in Asia and diplomatic relations between the United States and Asia are included in the papers and are supplemented by Rowe's correspondence with others involved in anti-communist organizations in the United States, most notably Marvin Liebman and Alfred Kohlberg.

Research materials relating to the Chinese agriculture development and technical assistance missions in Africa and Latin America from 1965 to 1971 are in the collection in the form of reports, photographs, pamphlets, and maps.
No arrangement was performed by archives staff and original folder titles are used when provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes prints and news clippings depicting Japanese propaganda posters. See also: Box 143.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes some photographs, large format glass negatives, large format negatives, and 35 mm negatives, some of which depict the Taiping Rebellion and Japanese propaganda in China.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Glass negatives may only be used under supervision.

scopecontent.p: Consists of 35 mm slides depicting Japanese propaganda posters. See also: Box 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Addressed to Mr. Frank P. Lockhart, Jr. at Princeton University. Sealed with red wax seals of the Embassy of the United States of AMerican in China.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Formerly security-classified records of the U.S. government, released in full or in part. Includes some interfield, unclassified government records. Arranged chronologically by date of release by Hoover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of memoranda and correspondence prepared for American delegates to the Conference on Limitation of Armament, as well as a report on Japanese immigration to the United States, arranged by form and thereunder chronologically by date of creation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of Council on Foreign Relations digests of discussions, memoranda, agendas, and lists (1941-1945), particularly from various study groups of the War and Peace Studies Project, as well as United States Information Service (USIS) correspondence and memoranda (1948), arranged by original folder title and thereunder chronologically by date of creation.
